original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week has flown by. Yesterday, I drove past the new house and saw that the front window was covered with boxes. We're eagerly anticipating receiving the keys at closing—I'm getting really excited! If everything goes smoothly this week, we'll be ready to close a week from Wednesday. Last night, I stayed up past 3:00 AM watching movies with Bethany. There's been a lot of movie watching happening here lately. Here's my recap: we watched "Thirteen" last night—a film every parent of a teenager should see. It surpassed my expectations. Then we watched "Gigli," which lived up to its poor reviews, but we had to see it for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer television used to be a wasteland filled with reruns, but now two exciting new shows have captured my attention. I've been watching both shows religiously over the past week. One of them, "Blow Out," features an unexpectedly flamboyant concept with hardly any visible LGBTQIA+ representation. It follows hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who is aiming to open a second branch of his widely successful West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Ordinarily, I wouldn't be interested at all. However, while flipping through channels, I happened upon Jonathan, who, with a mix of vanity and monotony, gazed at an empty space on Rodeo Drive and declared, "I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!" Strangely, I was hooked. Not since "Rocco" have I found a character this compelling on television, despite their apparent foolishness.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: What a week it's been... I'm dealing with tendonitis in my right shoulder, specifically under my shoulder blade. Whenever I overuse it, particularly with computer work, the pain is intense. At this point, I can hardly move my arm because I spent a lot of time updating my website and tackling other online tasks. Drawing takes much more effort now, and the lack of sleep only worsens the situation. While I'm not in the best spirits at the moment, I'm confident I'll recover soon. On a brighter note, my mom's surgery went well. Her eyesight is gradually returning; she can now discern fuzzy shapes and identify colors, although she remains significantly visually impaired. We're hopeful that she'll fully regain her vision soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished: The Kindness of Strangers... Today I attempted to do laundry with the kids and quickly discovered how even the simplest tasks can turn into daunting ordeals. Amidst the chaos, I also found out just how wonderfully kind strangers can be, expecting nothing in return other than the joy of being kind. Believe me, it wasn't like they were trying to impress me—I was disheveled, covered in kid drool, and wearing my trusty 'laundry day' attire. Plus, let’s just say my personal hygiene wasn't at its peak, so there was no scent-based motivation either! At this moment, I'm multitasking: writing this post while watching a collection of No Doubt music videos, all from the comfort of my desk in my room.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I find myself in my bedroom working on the computer of the personnel director from my job. I don't mind helping out, but I sometimes wonder why I so often end up fixing other people's computers as a favor. While I'm thankful to be able to support and care for others this way, I question where to draw the line before I'm being taken advantage of. Over the last couple of weeks, I've been staying up late reading and doing various activities, so I was looking forward to going to bed early tonight. However, I realized it would be more sensible to finish the computer repairs and return it to its owner. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So, I ended up watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Could you remind me what I wrote about previously? Or perhaps it's time for another installment in the "Is This a Date?" saga. Following our awkward lunch, my confidence wavered, and I realized I neglected to share a crucial part of the story with you all. Before Pat arrived for lunch, Dustin began talking about what a genuinely nice guy Pat is and mentioned his efforts to find him a girlfriend. As I listened and nodded, it became apparent that we were more focused on finding a match for Dustin's best friend than engaging in the typical conversation one might have with a stranger over pink lemonade. Excusing myself to the bathroom, I caught my reflection in the mirror and silently pondered: Am I being set up with someone else? Is this how things unfold now?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I encourage everyone to be thoughtful before taking action. In fact, I wish that every person in the world would take a moment to reflect before even getting out of bed in the morning, and then commit to maintaining that level of thoughtfulness throughout the day. If someone isn't ready to do so, perhaps they should consider staying in bed and opting for a restful sleep instead. I'm genuinely frustrated with careless behavior. While I don't claim to be the smartest person, my concerns aren't about intellectual challenges but rather common sense. Therefore, I think it's reasonable to hold people accountable for thoughtless actions. Let's see if I can limit this particular discussion to a few specific groups and save others for another time. Sound good? Great.

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished:
There are two issues with the scenario I discussed in my previous post: 

1. While it is true that Bush is stimulating the economy, he is doing so inefficiently. Robert Rubin, during his interview on NPR’s Marketplace, suggested that Bush could have stimulated the economy just as effectively without incurring long-term debt by implementing different types of tax cuts. These could have been temporary cuts aimed at benefiting low and middle-income individuals. Ah, Robert Rubin—the mere mention of his name is music to our ears. Quickly, try to name a Bush administration domestic cabinet official with Rubin's level of influence. Still thinking? It might take a while...

2. We cannot afford to give Republicans control only during wartime, as they have cleverly created an unending, global "war on terrorism.

original: 'she's saying i'm on the run, i'm chasing guys for fun' ~the offspring umm haven't updated in awhile but not much to say.. Went to the cove to see supernothing, they were good as usual, got to chill with tiago :-).. Sat. Went to work and then out w/ joe and rach, met up with steve, tiago and tom.. Came home at like quarter to 12 and woke up the next morning at quarter to 7 for a meet.. Got there a little late but it's all good, i did my full on floor and didn't fall, second on floor and vault and third on beam, 29.45 all around which isn't bad bc my meets get better as the season goes on..
polished: Haven't posted an update in a while, but here’s what I’ve been up to: Recently, I went to the cove to watch Supernothing perform, and as always, they were fantastic. I had a great time hanging out with Tiago. On Saturday, I worked and then spent the evening with Joe and Rach. We met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. I got home around 11:45 PM and was up early the next morning by 6:45 AM for a meet. Despite arriving a bit late, it went well—I completed my floor routine without any falls, securing second place on floor and vault and third on beam, resulting in an all-around score of 29.45. Not bad, considering my performance usually improves as the season progresses.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished: Have you ever experienced a moment when you start reflecting on life? Like when you're in math class, utterly bored, and you begin to wonder what processes in your brain enable you to understand math. You become aware of your own existence and question why you're there in that moment. It dawns on you how extraordinary it is just to be alive. Then, suddenly, you realize how ridiculous it is to be caught up in such a random train of thought. Has that ever happened to you? I really dislike it when it does. You know what else I can't stand? Block schedules. Who came up with that concept? It's obvious that sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class on any subject is nothing short of cruel and unusual punishment.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished: Monopoly has finally worn out its welcome in my life, and I hereby vow never to touch that dreaded iron game piece again. This evening, Andy narrowly defeated me by a few dollars and claimed victory in the game. Perhaps I let him win, considering he's leaving in just a few hours and I wanted him to enjoy his last night here. Whatever the case, it pales in comparison to the massive headache I’m experiencing right now. I've taken some Aleve, which seems to be doing its job; all I need now is some well-earned rest and relaxation. It was your phone that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive-in.

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: Today has been quite a long day. We just returned home from Indiana, and I realize I need to be selective about what I share, as there's a lot to say but limited time and energy. To begin, I must mention that camp was incredible, far exceeding my expectations. Recently, God's influence in my life has been truly remarkable, prompting a significant personal transformation. Now, back to the start: we arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and stayed there until we left for camp on Monday. During our stay, we spent our time visiting the fair, attending church, watching a parade, shopping at Walmart, and enjoying movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished: Today marks the end of my summer vacation—it's my last day! Unfortunately, I have a dentist appointment at 9 AM, which I really dislike. However, I'd prefer to take care of it now instead of trying to fit it in during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm feeling nervous, scared, and restless—basically, all the emotions one associates with not wanting to return to school. This is going to be an entirely new experience for me. As a perfectionist, I take pride in excelling at everything I do, but starting something new is always challenging. I dislike feeling like just a pawn (as I told Cassie, "I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight") and not understanding what's happening.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had, as early as 1996, forewarned of the looming threat of the emergence of a so-called "third Islamic state" in the region. T. V. Rajeswar, who previously led the Intelligence Bureau and now serves as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had anticipated this serious danger in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times back in 1996. Shourie puts forth an important question by asking whether knowing that Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, authored these warnings makes them more credible. Alternatively, should we dismiss Rajeswar as a covert communalist unfit to continue as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh simply because he penned such forecasts?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. Akcron is right about the problems with the shower, it sucks, in terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self torture can be pretty entertaining.
polished: Attitude: bored; Mood: indifferent. I'm looking forward to tonight as it's been a long, hard day at work, leaving me almost no time to write for you, dear readers. It's encouraging to see Tigger, now known as Akcron, stepping up and sharing her thoughts. There's not much to report today, but yesterday I attended Shakespeare on the Green. It was a beautiful play, although I had to leave before the curtain call, which was disappointing. I hope to watch a full performance of a Shakespeare play someday. But I digress. Akcron is right about the shower problems—it's a nuisance. On a lighter note, you have to admit, watching someone struggle in the shower can be quite amusing, given the expressions people make during such moments of self-inflicted torture.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished: Suddenly, over the past two days, I've been overwhelmed with intense exhaustion—utterly debilitating fatigue. Last evening, I went home and immediately fell asleep, only waking when my mother called at around eight-thirty. When I awoke, the room was completely dark, as I hadn’t turned on any lights. For a few seconds, I was disoriented about the time and date, just my mother's voice guiding me back to reality. I wonder why I’m feeling so drained... The weather is pleasant this morning. It was drizzling as I arrived. Meanwhile, I've heard that in Calcutta, it has been raining for the last three days.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was particularly frustrating. I ended up discarding the sweater I was working on, even though I had completed about 14 inches. I lost approximately $10 worth of yarn, with each skein costing $8. Unfortunately, by the time I reached the armholes, there were too many stitches, and the mohair kept tangling as I knitted. Trying to undo the rows, known as frogging, was ineffective because the yarn frequently snapped. Despite my usual tendency to swear in such situations, I remained surprisingly calm. Instead, I just listened to the second season of "Sex and the City" (thanks to my library) while I unraveled my work in a rather gloomy manner. Eventually, I grew tired and decided to throw it away. Looking back, I guess I can say I learned a lot from attempting to make this sweater.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we explored this week's assigned reading: Edward S. Casey's "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World." The first chapter, "Implacement," and the second, "Displacement," delved into how our modern world emphasizes time as the key framework: we are constantly racing against time, trying to save it, or catching up just in time. Casey argues that centering culture around place fosters a more rooted community. (This is a brief summary, offered humbly in case my professor or any classmates read this post.) So far, this book is the first in our course that has truly captivated my interest.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: Whatever mysterious ingredients are used to color freeze pops should come with a warning: they might add a touch of the bizarre to your life. While laughter is certainly enjoyable, one might question whether we would have ended up on that fire escape, drinking beer in the strong wind, had we not indulged in freeze pops earlier. As we found ourselves huddling in the doorway of a bar, sadly closed for the night, we paused to peruse an office-supplies catalog that had slipped through the mail. It was fortunate we did so. Who would have anticipated that tucked within its pages were the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not me. Here’s a short list: purchase 36 permanent marker pens and receive a stunt kite, or buy 30 lever arch files and get a complementary barbecue.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished: Currently playing: "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero. Now, onto my post... Senate Republicans, let's see a show of hands—who tuned in for last week's 39-hour judicial nomination marathon? I must admit, I caught parts of it. This massive waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans upset that Democrats refused to simply nod along and approve four of Bush's extreme judicial nominees. Despite Democrats having already confirmed 168 of Bush's selections, this wasn't satisfactory for the Republicans craving power. They mistakenly believe they have a sweeping mandate for such antics.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished: This past weekend was truly enjoyable. I indulged in nature's finest greenery, listened to Nevermore—a band I wish I had explored much earlier—and spent much of my time reading. I managed to finish three books: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" offered an engaging cyberpunk journey through a near-future United States plagued by global warming and chaos. The book was clever, well-paced, and convincing. However, I must admit that I didn't come away with a strong impression of the story or its characters. While both are well-developed and vividly described, the book struck me as good, but not exceptional.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished: The aftermath of returning from practicum has been challenging. During the first week, I struggled significantly, but it's in this second week that things have started to become clearer. The post-practicum distress seems to be a widespread issue that is just now gaining attention. I was deeply affected, but a meeting with the course coordinator provided relief. This meeting allowed me to voice my concerns and, in doing so, ensure that no one else would be placed in a similarly inadequate practicum environment. Yesterday, I encountered a distressed classmate who was adamant about warning another student scheduled for her previous school about its poor quality. I managed to calm her down, suggesting that it would be more effective to approach the administrator first.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished: Life here can be incredibly hectic at times, yet there is always an opportunity for stress-relieving activities. I've discovered that I'm not very skilled at either 8-ball or ping pong! Rick, affectionately known as "the Canuck," frequently defeats me. We have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, making it easy to squeeze in a 'quick round.' Last night, I took part in an 8-ball tournament at the recreation tent, our social hub complete with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, a dartboard, and, of course, a ping pong table. I performed quite well through my game—up until I accidentally pocketed the cue ball while aiming for the eight ball. Despite this setback, I had a reasonably good time, with the highlight being the participation of two Dutch soldiers in the tournament.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished: In the fall of 1974, it felt like the thirteenth attempt to conquer the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I wasn't then, nor am I now, someone who naturally gravitates towards mathematics. In fact, I have a strong aversion to it. You get the picture: I am truly math-phobic. As I endeavored to unravel the mysteries of algebra, the doorbell unexpectedly rang. Reluctantly, I set down my book to answer the door, only to find no one there. Frustrated, I returned to my studies, and just as I began to grasp a fleeting moment of clarity, the doorbell disrupted my thoughts once more. Instantly, my fragile breakthrough vanished. Once again, I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. It was exactly what a struggling math student didn't need—an unwelcome prank.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been incredibly exhausting. From Tuesday to Thursday, I was immersed in transitioning to my new classroom. The new space is larger and conveniently closer to my grade level team—factors I must keep in mind as I dedicate countless hours to preparing it for this school year. If I had known about the move before the school year ended, I would have sorted through and discarded many of the books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, everything accompanied me to the new room. Thus, this week was consumed by moving, unpacking, and extensive decluttering. I owe a huge thanks to my teammate Jill for her invaluable help. Despite still teaching in my old room this month, she and her wonderful students managed to move nearly all of my belongings for me!

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished: No matter how much I might try, I cannot deny it: a part of you will always reside within me. Despite never having been your spouse, without bearing your child, and without ever being officially recognized as your partner, my love for you was profound. Even now, that love resonates within my heart. I am forever reminded of those rare nights we shared, when our hearts and bodies intertwined in a soulful embrace, enveloped by the salty darkness of an evening by the sea—or a kiss shared in the rain. Whenever a shadow pierces my heart, I find you there. That fragment of you continues to pulse with the eternal love we once shared, a love that still endures. For heri.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I feel uneasy about investigative reporting; it doesn't sit right with me. To clarify, the particular article I'm working on and its implications make me uncomfortable. I suspect this is because I don't fully believe in it, which prevents me from truly grasping its essence—its underlying intensity and the fervent drive to challenge the status quo. I grew up in a country where questioning authority was unheard of. Doing so could get you shot or imprisoned under strict security laws. I'm not accustomed to this freedom of speech or to openly questioning things. Admittedly, I can be a difficult person to get along with.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished: Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I went on an outing to Guintubdan, La Carlota. For most of us, it was a new experience. We embarked on a trek to the falls, which took about 30 minutes. The uphill walk left us breathless, but we persevered and reached our destination. The water was icy cold, enough to make our bodies feel numb. We didn't linger for long, less than an hour, before setting off to explore another nearby waterfall, involving another 30-minute hike. Although challenging, the journey was truly rewarding. The falls exuded a sense of tranquility, and the entire scene was breathtaking. It felt as though we were in harmony with nature. Immersing myself in the chilly water provided a profound connection to nature, and the cool air and water were soothing enough to lull anyone into a tranquil state.

original: Well i am sure my sisters are drunk off their butts. Today was pride in san diego. I know my sisters and when it is drinking time, it is drinking time. I realized this a while ago, though. My hope is that Ed can stay until Bailey's surgery. We've been monitoring Bailey's swelling closely, and it’s indeed significant.

polished: On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, believing that the Easter egg hunt hosted by the firemen was scheduled for 11 a.m. Unfortunately, it had actually taken place on Friday. Thankfully, I had brought a bag of eggs with me just in case, so Connor still had a wonderful time searching for eggs in the park. On Sunday morning, Connor was thrilled to discover that the Easter Bunny had visited. There is nothing more heartwarming than witnessing the delight on your child's face. After the egg hunt, we all attended church. While the idea of the 'Easter Bunny' is fun, we ensure our children understand the true meaning of the holiday. It was Megan's first Easter, and she looked absolutely adorable in her jean dress and stockings!

Friday, November 22, 2002

Woohoo! My boots have arrived at my house! I completely forgot and had them delivered to my home instead of my workplace, so I have to wait another four hours before I can see them. Argh! These are the Face boots and Tredair Flame boots. I rock!

I somehow ended up with a flat tire. Fortunately, I'm at work, so the guys are going to inflate it for me and make sure it holds air. If it doesn't, they'll change my tire and put on the spare. Thankfully, my spare is full-sized. I might have the chance to buy a new tire tonight—woohoo! Hamad Tire, here I come! I thought I had found another VW.

original: I know in a previous post i protected parents, almost even taking their side, well here's my little change of mind. Parents don't know anything. They think they know you soooo well, maybe even to the point where they can read emotions off your face. They can't. Parents know nothing about us. And when i go upstairs after arguing with nicole about kelli, like i just did a few minutes ago, and they want me to tell them what's wrong. Yeah, how about you shut the fuck up!? i don't have to tell you what's wrong all the time. Here's the situation with nicole and kelli. Kelli and nicole don't like each other. At all.
polished: In a previous post, I expressed a certain level of understanding towards parents, perhaps even siding with them. However, I've had a change of heart. Parents often believe they understand us completely, even assuming they can discern our emotions just by looking at us. The truth is, they don't. They hardly know us at all. After a recent argument I had with Nicole about Kelli, my parents wanted me to explain what was bothering me. Honestly, it's frustrating. I don't always have to share my troubles with them. To give some context, Kelli and Nicole simply do not get along, and that's the issue at hand.

original: Urllink some people are jumping to connect urllink this dot : the urllink organization for security and cooperation in europe was invited to monitor the election by the state department. The observers will come from the osce's office for democratic institutions and human rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a u.s. Presidential election. With urllink this dot : a baker's dozen of congressional democrats, among them four new yorkers, has petitioned u.n. Secretary- general kofi annan to dispatch international observers to florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on the info available, the osce seems to be coming here to learn from the u.s. Election process, not to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for u.n.
polished: Some individuals are eager to connect this idea: the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) has been invited by the U.S. State Department to monitor the upcoming election. Observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This marks the first time such a team will be present for a U.S. presidential election. Alongside this development, a group of thirteen congressional Democrats, including four representatives from New York, has requested that U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan send international observers to Florida to oversee this year's presidential voting. I respectfully disagree with this notion. Based on the available information, it appears that the OSCE is here to learn from the U.S. election process, rather than oversee it, countering the original partisan and immature suggestion for U.N. involvement.

polished: A lot has been happening with me lately. For instance, Debbie and I argued over which china I was allowed to use. Seriously, who uses enough fancy china to serve an entire choir? She had everything—saucers, teapots, coffee cups, wine goblets, water glasses, and seven different kinds of forks and spoons, not to mention dinner plates, salad plates, dessert plates, soup bowls, and side bowls. I was genuinely overwhelmed! Then, she got upset with me for snacking on appetizers while the turkey was still cooking. I tried to reassure her that I would indeed eat the meal. And after all of that, I had to take my father to the hospital.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished:
Republican Party Faces Criticism Over Voter Registration at Naturalization Ceremonies

Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville will be relocated due to concerns following allegations that Republican activists were registering new citizens as members of their party. Reported by Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the citizenship ceremony initially proceeded as expected, with nearly 200 attendees taking part and becoming new Americans. Just before leaving the event on June 29, an immigration official encouraged these new citizens to visit a voter registration table—an ordinary feature at such ceremonies. However, this table was different: Republican volunteers were distributing the forms, and the party affiliation box had already been pre-checked to register each new voter as a Republican. This appeared suspicious to Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished: I've always taken pride in ensuring that everyone who visits Casa Pescatore feels as comfortable as possible, hoping they feel as at home as they would in their own residence. Yesterday, I aimed to achieve just that. A large crowd gathered on Perry Avenue, with an air of what some might view as 'intense anticipation.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a generous pan of baked ziti. The tables were prepared, the food I had cooked spread out, and the atmosphere was filled with excitement. To my delight, before I knew it, my dear friend from Florida, whom I had missed dearly, walked through the door. His visit was even more special as he brought along his expecting wife, giving me the closest experience yet to being an uncle. I pampered her with an abundance of food and trays of tiramisu.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I found the concept of treating flag-burning as an offense intriguing, as it might have offered historical figures accused of witchcraft an alternative fate. As a non-American blogger, I've been hesitant to weigh in on certain debates, especially those concerning flags. However, given that I initiated the topic (though not the act of flag-burning), I should probably express my views. To begin with, I find the idea of enacting a law against flag-burning entirely irrational. When we start granting any symbol—regardless of its nature—an unquestioning reverence and legal protection, we take a significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently ambiguous; they don’t intrinsically stand for anything. What matters is the meaning we assign to them or how they are perceived.

original: 1. Everyone is obsessed with one movie or series of movies, what's yours? evil dead series.. If it wasn't obvious. (i have one of the largest 'stuff from that movie series' collections ever) 2. Can you play an instrument? what is it? bass guitar, oh yes, i rock out. 3. Biggest money wasting vice? either my compulsive buying of dvds or any new technology. 4. Have any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? no, no, and i must bank-face all moneys in my wallet in order from least to greatest at all times. 5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? because i said so.
polished:
1. Everyone has a favorite movie or series they're obsessed with. What's yours? For me, it's definitely the "Evil Dead" series—it's hard to miss my passion, given that I own one of the biggest collections related to those films.

2. Do you play any musical instruments? I certainly do! I'm a bass guitarist, and I love to rock out.

3. What's your biggest money-wasting habit? I'm torn between my tendency to impulsively purchase DVDs and my addiction to acquiring the latest technology.

4. Do you have any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? While I have no phobias or allergies, I do have a compulsion: I must organize the money in my wallet with all banknotes facing the same way, sorted from the smallest to the largest denomination.

5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? Simply put—because I said so.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: Hello! I watched "Troy" with my family tonight, and overall, I wasn't very impressed. I'm too tired to go into detail, but I felt the movie had potential. Unfortunately, too much focus seemed to be placed on the impressive set design rather than on establishing a cohesive tone or theme. While it retold the story effectively, I didn’t find it particularly engaging, nor did I feel that I gained anything from the experience. The character development was quite weak, in my opinion. Additionally, the musical score seemed lacking and felt like an imitation of the one in "Gladiator." In "Gladiator," the background music, featuring a woman's voice, was effective because it reinforced a genuinely compelling story.

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished: Introducing PulpFiction 1.0 from Freshly Squeezed Software, the latest entrant in the realm of Atom/RDF/RSS readers! This application offers a wealth of features typical of native apps. However, as a heads-up, it's not freely available, which is a recurring topic of interest online. You can explore PulpFiction with a 15-day trial before deciding to either revert to other options or invest $25 to continue usage. One standout feature is that each post is treated as an individual item that can be easily moved, stored, labeled, or deleted—an aspect likely to delight news trackers. Additionally, PulpFiction supports OPML import and export, aligning with standard expectations.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: Today, I find myself missing my sister deeply. It's odd not having her around, playfully annoying me (just kidding...). Even though she was only here for a week, her presence was truly impactful, and I mean that positively. Working on the scrapbook from our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories, even though it was just last week. Perhaps it's the thought of not seeing her for a long time, with her moving to Bristol in September or October. She symbolized a deeper connection to my family back home, and I miss them all dearly. Tomorrow marks the beginning of a new term—how quickly the holidays have flown by!

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. To those of you choosing to continue on i offer the following observation. ' sometimes i wish i'd been given the manual .' manuals, if done correctly at least, let you know: what things are for, what they can do, how they do the things they do, what happens if you push button x or y, what to do if things aren't doing what they're supposed to the phone number and email address of the omniscient guru who can solve every problem very useful information. Unfortunately i didn't get a manual with me.
polished: Have you ever had one of those days where nothing seems to make sense? If you haven't, feel free to skip this, as it might not resonate with you. For those who decide to read on, I offer this thought: sometimes I wish I had been given a manual. A well-crafted manual would explain everything—what each thing is for, its capabilities, how it functions, what happens when you press certain buttons, and what to do when things go awry. It would even provide the contact information for the all-knowing expert who can solve every issue—a truly valuable resource. Unfortunately, it seems I didn't come with a manual.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: There's nothing wrong with PCs—if I were an avid gamer with the time to dedicate, I'd definitely own a PC system for its expansive selection of games. However, aside from a few unique titles, the extensive array of games at CompUSA tends to feel repetitive after a while. Initially, I feel envious, but soon I notice that it's essentially just a myriad of variations on the same theme—first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, and simulations. The endless versions of "Age of Empires" become almost laughable: "AOE with orcs," "AOE with spaceships," "AOE with fuzzy wombats." It's reminiscent of the countless movie trailers that begin with, "In a world...

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
Subject: Urgent: Impact of ISO Rule Changes on PX Day Ahead Auction

To: All PX Market Participants  
From: John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer  
Date: Monday, December 11, 2000

I am writing to address a critical issue affecting the PX Day Ahead Auction caused by recent rule changes implemented by the California ISO. The emergency tariff filing submitted last Friday has disrupted the continuity of our market operations. The introduction of both soft and hard caps has created a significant disconnect, posing unacceptable risks for all participants. Contrary to the ISO's intentions of decreasing real-time energy sales and procurement, this approach is likely to drive suppliers towards the more lucrative pricing opportunities offered by the ISO. In response, the PX is actively petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to permit immediate submission of adjustment bids at any relevant price for already submitted schedules. We believe this is necessary to restore stability and ensure competitive market dynamics.

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished:
Subject: Important Update: Control Area Reserves Service from BPA

Hello Mark,

I wanted to bring to your attention a message from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette.

Effective immediately, Enron has secured control area reserves services from BPA. This allows the sale of unit-contingent energy on an hourly firm basis because BPA is providing reserves for up to 60 minutes. If Grays Harbor Paper experiences a unit derate or outage, RT should promptly inform BPA dispatch and adjust the schedule during the next ramp. For instance, if the Grays unit trips at 13:33, RT would notify BPA and ensure that by the top of the next hour (14:00), the schedule for he 14:00 is reduced to zero. Please note that BPA will maintain the schedule for a maximum of 60 minutes.

Best regards,
Bill

Rod:

Here are their credit concerns:

1. They want to modify the cross-default language by adding a clause that states a cross-default isn't triggered unless the non-defaulting party, in good faith, determines that the defaulting party's ability to fulfill its obligations under the master agreement is "endangered."

2. For a credit event upon a merger, we had suggested replacing the "materially weaker" standard with the stipulation that it means being rated below BBB- by S&P. Do you have strong opinions on this matter?

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished:
Khyatt (non-privileged).pst - El Paso Tests Market for Mainline Expansion 

El Paso Natural Gas received a clear message when its last open season for 1.2 billion cubic feet per day (bcf/d) of firm transportation capacity garnered bids totaling 14.4 bcf/d. In response, the company has launched an open season to assess market interest in expanding its mainline and address regulatory concerns regarding the capacity constraints at the California border. El Paso is facing significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand due to California's immense demand and soaring prices. In a letter dated January 3, Daniel M. Adamson, Director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, urged El Paso to consider modifying its Line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" currently affecting the California gas market.

original: Kmann.nsf hi john, i'm out of town, but will give this a look when i return. Kay j.nassos@pecorp.com on 01/30/2001 05:16:08 pm to: kay.mann@enron.com cc: gregg.penman@enron.com, t.hermann@pecorp.com, r.dobson@pecorp.com subject: confidentiaility agreements regarding enovate hello kay - it's been a long time since we've last spoken and i hope things are well. In november, gregg penman had sent me two confidentiality agreements related to enovate and asked that i forward any comments to you directly. I finally have reviewed them and have a couple comments. original: Mgrigsb.nsf ? over the weekend, gov. Davis and senate polance made an informal agreement whereby senate polance has agreed to sponsor the socal mou bill. Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. The bill would first go to the senate energy committee. Sen. Bowen, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the mou, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a socal bankruptcy increases.
polished: Over the weekend, Governor Davis and Senator Polanco reached an informal agreement in which Senator Polanco agreed to sponsor the SoCal MOU bill. Polanco, a Democrat, is currently embroiled in a personal scandal that has reportedly left his political career in jeopardy. Instead of seeking another term in the Senate, Polanco plans to run for Mayor of Los Angeles. The bill is anticipated to be introduced during the new extraordinary session, starting today or tomorrow. Initially, it will be reviewed by the Senate Energy Committee. However, the committee's chair, Senator Bowen, is staunchly opposed to the MOU. Consequently, the bill is expected to be tied up in committee hearings for a significant period. Prolonged involvement in committee politics and potential amendments increase the probability of a bankruptcy for SoCal.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
Subject: Notice of CFTC Approval of New NYMEX Rule 6.40C

Date: October 3, 2000

To all NYMEX and COMEX Members,

From: Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President

I am writing to inform you that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has approved the implementation of NYMEX Rule 6.40C, titled "Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants." This newly approved rule, which aligns with a recent CFTC advisory, is now in effect. 

Rule 6.40C allows Futures Commission Merchants (FCMs), under certain specified conditions, to utilize their own internal, proprietary systems for generating Average Price (AP) calculations. This applies when multiple prices are received on a single order or a series of orders. The full details of this rule are attached for your reference. 

Please review this information carefully to ensure compliance. 

Thank you.

polished:
Subject: Central Illinois Confirmation

Dear Patrice,

I would like to confirm the usage of the following strategy for flexible pricing. Please consider deleting the last sentence regarding the "keep whole" clause, as it does not account for force majeure conditions.

Flexible Pricing: During the delivery period of the transaction, the customer may request a price different from the original contract price—whether it's a fixed price or otherwise—by contacting the company during pricing hours. The request must specify the quantity of gas to be scheduled for selected months within the delivery period. Please note that this request should be made before 12:00 noon Central Time.

Thank you,  
Debra Perlingiere  

P.S. Please call me when you arrive.

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished: As of this week, EnronOnline has begun offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. In my role of reviewing the eligibility of counterparties to engage in these transactions online, I examine the financial trading agreement database for any listed restrictions, evaluate the master swap agreement, and review any board resolutions received at the time the master agreement was executed. Historically, when we requested resolutions to confirm the authority to engage in master agreements or derivative transactions, these resolutions often did not permit counterparties to conduct currency transactions. Entering into currency transactions with our energy customers represents a new business endeavor for us, so it's important to ensure we carefully examine these old resolutions and avoid relying solely on the "restrictions" noted in Lotus Notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished:
Dhyvl.nsf Dave, I would be pleased to create the transaction agreement form; however, I have several questions:

1. Could you clarify the relationship between the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on the Northwest Pipeline? Specifically, is the transport positioned upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If it is downstream, why is EWEB not contracting for it?

2. What is the daily volume being sold? You mention the term DCQ and also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity, which is unusual since typically, there would be no tolerance with a DCQ transaction.

3. Is this transaction intended to meet requirements? Is the price consistent for volumes that exceed the estimated quantity, up to an additional 20%?

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished: The spreadsheet below, provided by Jdasovic.nsf, outlines the implicit commodity charges based on the effective date of four different rates within the same rate schedule (Schedule DR). The schedule in effect from August 2000 to September 2000 results in a significantly higher commodity charge due to a lump sum reimbursement that SDG&E customers receive over those two months, leading to lower expected electric bills. If the lump sum reimbursement is excluded from the implicit energy component, the average from June 2000 to January 2001 is 6.2 cents, whereas the average implicit commodity from February 2001 to December 2001 is 7.3 cents. Overall, the average implicit commodity charge from June 2000 to December 2001 is 6.9 cents per unit. For deliveries starting on September 1, 2000, the average remains 6.9 cents.

original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished:
Subject: Week-in-Review: Positive Developments and Strategic Moves

Greetings,

These past weeks have indeed been challenging for all of us. I hope that my daily updates are providing clarity on the latest developments within our company. Here’s a summary of last week’s important events:

We finalized a commitment letter with JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney, securing additional credit lines of $1 billion. These will be supported by our Northern Natural Gas Company and Transwestern Pipeline Company. In total, we now have $4 billion in secured credit lines. This boost will help us pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain our liquidity.

Furthermore, our board of directors has welcomed a new member, William Powers, Jr., the esteemed Dean of the University of Texas School of Law in Austin.

Best regards,

[Your Name]

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but pge was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with jan 01 and promises further orders regarding dec 00 and benchmark prices through april 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16000). With respect to sales to california, we have concluded at least one short term sale and have talked with cal dept of water resources about longer term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last i heard.
polished: I've attached the FERC order and staff recommendations from the Skean.nsf file. The order outlines the possibility of $69 million in refunds, requiring either payment or cost justification. Although Enron is not listed among the 13 entities accused of overcharging, PGE is, with an allegation of $3.18 million. This is not the end of the matter. The order currently addresses only January 2001 and indicates that further directives will cover December 2000 and establish benchmark prices through April 2001. The pricing used to determine potential refunds was quite high, at $273/MWh, incorporating gas prices, emissions costs, and an assumed heat rate exceeding 16,000. Regarding sales to California, we have finalized at least one short-term transaction and held discussions with the California Department of Water Resources about longer-term agreements. However, the last update indicated that we were still encountering issues with credit.

polished:
Mike Maggi (Non-privileged).pst

Subject: Re: What?

Date: Monday, November 26, 2001 8:34 AM

From: Michelle Nelson

To: Mike Maggi

Michelle: "Are you serious? You can easily pick up toothpaste from the store in the other building. Did you forget to brush your teeth this morning?"

Mike: "I forgot to pack my toothpaste... long story. Do you happen to have any?"

Michelle's Previous Message: Sent Monday, November 26, 2001, 8:31 AM - "It was good. I guess."

Mike's Previous Message: Sent Monday, November 26, 2001, 8:33 AM - "No, I haven't heard anything. Do you have any toothpaste?

original: Cgerman.nsf i entered volume and pricing on the following 2 deals in sitara; deal 418015 cng citygate with tenn prod plus transport pricing. Deal 418065 cgas citygate with trco and cglf production pricing and trco, cglf, and cgas transport pricing (this will take a while to do). Do we want to turn the auto-confirms off? i think every time i create a vng deal, a confirm is faxed to them. And if anyone has a better was of doing the deals ( should we show these as production area sales), please let me know. The easiest way i can come up with is to enter the sales at the citygate or storage facility and have most of the pricing done in a worksheet.
polished: I have entered the volume and pricing details for the following two deals in Sitara: Deal 418015 for CNG citygate with Tenn production plus transport pricing, and Deal 418065 for CGas citygate with TRCO and CGLF production pricing, alongside TRCO, CGLF, and CGas transport pricing (please note that this process may take some time to complete). Should we consider disabling the auto-confirmations? It seems that whenever I create a VNG deal, a confirmation is automatically faxed to the parties involved. If anyone has a more efficient method for handling these deals—perhaps by categorizing them as production area sales—please share your ideas. The simplest approach I can suggest is to record the sales at the citygate or storage facility and handle most of the pricing via a spreadsheet.

original: It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exeed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash free, lots of story/content to put you through, options for each and every day such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships) and even games. This review is purely based on playing mycareer, and so far it's 10/10. Facescan worked really well for me (used it two times, first one made me have a downsyndrome forehead though..). Keep in mind, using the mynba2k17 app will allow for you to facescan for free and allow you to earn daily vc. #sellout
polished: This game truly captivates, leaving nothing but positive impressions. It surpasses all my expectations and is likely to exceed yours as well.
