The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".
polished: Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has voiced strong criticism regarding the vast sums of money spent on the Iraq war and conflicts in the Middle East, arguing that these funds would have been better used to alleviate poverty. As the leader of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, he shared his thoughts on BBC Radio 4 and planned to emphasize his perspective during his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas address, he condemned the Iraq war as a "terrible" misuse of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have publicly opposed the war. On the BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day segment, the cardinal highlighted the misallocation of "billions" towards warfare instead of efforts to lift people out of severe poverty, malnourishment, and disease. He urged for 2005 to become a pivotal year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished:
British Stars Missed Out on Major Oscars

Hopes for British success at the Oscars were disappointed as UK stars went home empty-handed in the acting and directing categories. Despite receiving three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not clinch the awards for either Best Director or Best Screenplay, and lead actress Imelda Staunton also went unrecognized. Kate Winslet was bested by Hilary Swank for Best Actress, and both Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo fell short in their bids for Best Supporting Actor. However, Andrea Arnold from the UK emerged victorious, winning the Short Film Award for her gripping drama, "Wasp." Reflecting on her win, Arnold, who was a presenter on children's television shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, described the experience as "totally overwhelming." "Wasp," which tells the story of a single mother struggling to get by, triumphed over entries by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished: Debra Hill, the screenwriter and producer best known for her role in creating the 1970s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54 after battling cancer. Hill co-wrote the 1978 film, which featured Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter haunted by a psychopath. Under the direction of John Carpenter, the film grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) globally, setting a record for independent films at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, she started her career as a production assistant, advancing through the industry to become an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Hill is celebrated as a trailblazer for women in film, taking on roles during the 1970s that were typically filled by men.

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished: According to recent research, high-speed broadband is significantly empowering individuals to express themselves online. A study by the UK think-tank Demos reveals that one in four broadband users in Britain regularly uploads content and maintains personal websites. The report highlights that the availability of constant, fast internet connections is transforming how people engage with the web. Currently, over five million households in the UK are equipped with broadband, and this figure continues to rise rapidly. The Demos report investigates the influence of broadband on users' online behaviors, discovering that more than half of broadband users access the internet before having breakfast. Moreover, one in five users confessed to waking up in the middle of the night specifically to browse the web. The report further emphasizes that broadband is motivating individuals to take a more engaged and participative approach to the online world.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.
polished: Yukos Returns to U.S. Courts: The Russian oil and gas company, Yukos, is scheduled to appear in a U.S. court on Thursday as it continues its struggle for survival. The Russian authorities are dismantling the firm to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt. In response, Yukos sought bankruptcy protection in the U.S., hoping to leverage international business law to halt the compulsory sale of its crucial oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. Despite these efforts, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to the state-run oil company Rosneft, but not before the state auction was interrupted. Yukos' legal team now argues that the auction breached U.S. bankruptcy laws. The company and its principal shareholders have pledged to pursue any entity that acquires its assets, utilizing every available legal avenue.

original: Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top us dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to us research think-tank pew internet and american life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.
polished: Voters are eagerly participating in the annual Bloggies, which honor the best blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official website experienced an overwhelming surge in traffic, causing a temporary shutdown. This year, blogs have been nominated across 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs have gained significant prominence, with "blog" being named the word of the year for 2004 by a leading U.S. dictionary. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 new blogs are created daily. According to Pew Internet and American Life, a U.S.-based research organization, a new blog is launched every 5.8 seconds. However, less than 40% of these blogs are updated at least once every two months.

original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.
polished: According to Chinese state media, the China Three Gorges Project Corporation is defying a government directive to halt the construction of one of its massive dams. Despite orders, the company responsible for building the Three Gorges Dam is proceeding with the construction of the Xiluodu Dam, as reported by the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale projects ordered to stop due to insufficient environmental assessments. Instead of complying, the company may choose to pay fines, as suggested by the Beijing News. Additionally, the firm has disregarded instructions to cease work on two other projects: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 out of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to perform mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the suspension order.

original: Man city 0-2 man utd manchester united reduced chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over manchester city. Wayne rooney met gary neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off richard dunne, to put united ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate dunne hooked a volley over david james' head and into his own net. Steve mcmanaman wasted city's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes united had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a paul scholes header over the bar.
polished: Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's lead in the Premier League to nine points following a determined 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney capitalized on Gary Neville's cross to the near post by delivering a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne, giving United the lead. Shortly after, an unfortunate Dunne inadvertently volleyed the ball over goalkeeper David James and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best opportunity by missing the target from three yards out in the first half. In the initial 45 minutes, United appeared unlikely to secure the crucial win needed to keep their title hopes alive. Their play was more sluggish than strategic, resulting in only one notable chance—a header by Paul Scholes that sailed over the bar.

original: Wales 'must learn health lessons' the new health minister for wales says there are lessons to learn from england in tackling waiting lists. Dr brian gibbons, on his first full day in the job after jane hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both plaid cymru and the liberal democrats said dr gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile ms hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda. Dr gibbons, who was a gp in blaengwynfi, in the upper afan valley, before becoming am for aberavon, said nhs staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems which had faced ms hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in wales.
polished: The newly appointed Health Minister for Wales emphasized the importance of learning from England's approach to addressing waiting lists. On his first complete day in office following Jane Hutt's dismissal, Dr. Brian Gibbons acknowledged the "significant challenges" ahead but affirmed that the "fundamentals" were already established. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats expressed the need for Dr. Gibbons to revise existing policies. In her defense, Ms. Hutt argued that waiting times and lists constituted "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, formerly a GP in Blaengwynfi in the Upper Afan Valley before becoming Assembly Member for Aberavon, indicated that NHS staff desired a phase of stability after extensive change and reform. An ongoing issue during Ms. Hutt's tenure as the Assembly's inaugural Health Minister was the prolonged waiting lists in Wales.

original: Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. "that was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the old trafford boss. "we showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. "i look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while arsenal and chelsea have yet to come and villa may have some players back when they do." ferguson also hailed senior stars ryan giggs and roy keane, who came off the bench for the injured john o'shea. "roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.
polished: Sir Alex Ferguson has commended Manchester United’s tenacity following their gritty performance in the 1-0 victory over Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away match of the season, and it was a thrilling game of football—dynamic, with excellent passing," remarked the Old Trafford manager. "We displayed immense character and determination; losing was not an option for us. Looking at that match, I feel quite accomplished knowing we've won there, whereas Arsenal and Chelsea still have to visit, and Villa might have some players back by then." Ferguson also expressed admiration for veteran players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who stepped in for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy brought the calmness we required in the midfield, something that no other player can offer," he added.

original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. A different story will screen in the panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 february. It features the singer talking about both his career and his personal life, from his days in wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 february. Director southan morris and executive producer andy stephens will also attend the festival. The 93 minute film will see michael discussing his early days in wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label sony and his stance against the iraq war and american politics.
polished: A documentary offering an unfiltered glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be featured at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Titled "A Different Story," the film will be screened in the Panorama section of the festival, which takes place from February 10 to 20. The documentary includes candid discussions by Michael covering both his illustrious career and personal journey, from his early years with Wham! to more recent events. George Michael will be present at the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Accompanying him will be the film's director, Southan Morris, and executive producer, Andy Stephens. The 93-minute film delves into Michael's beginnings with Wham!, his subsequent solo career, his legal disputes with Sony, and his outspoken views on the Iraq War and American politics.

original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.
polished: For the first time, digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from digital music sales, which were previously tracked only on a separate download chart. Currently, Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is positioned at number two on Billboard's Pop Chart and leads the Digital Chart. The incorporation of download sales into the UK singles chart is planned for later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to the creation of Billboard's Hot Digital Sales Chart. Now, these digital sales will be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to form the updated Hot 100 chart. Another new chart, the Pop 100, also merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay data to US radio stations that feature chart music.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.
polished: The so-called "spam king" of the internet, Scott Richter, is now seeking bankruptcy protection as anti-spam laws take their toll. Richter, who runs OptInRealBig.com and has sent billions of spam emails, claims that ongoing legal challenges have driven the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. One of the primary legal battles OptInRealBig is facing is with Microsoft, which is demanding millions of dollars in damages. The company believes that filing for Chapter 11 will allow it to address its legal challenges while continuing its business operations. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by the junk mail monitoring group Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for distributing emails that breached anti-spam regulations. The lawsuit was initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who accuse Richter and his cohorts of sending billions of spam emails through 514 compromised internet addresses across 35 countries.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. There had been newspaper speculation that santini had felt undermined by arnesen's role at the club. "it is absolutely not true," arnesen told bbc radio five live. "there is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. "he has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But i trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.
polished: Frank Arnesen, the sporting director of Tottenham, has dismissed claims of a conflict with coach Jacques Santini, asserting that Santini's resignation was not due to a personality clash at White Hart Lane. Recent media reports suggested that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's position at the club. However, Arnesen countered these assertions in an interview with BBC Radio Five Live, stating, "That is absolutely not true. The only reason for his resignation is his personal issues." Arnesen mentioned that Santini had recently communicated to him that the matter was strictly personal. Despite this, Arnesen admitted he could not provide details about the personal issues that led Santini to step down after just 13 games in charge. He remarked, "Jacques has never shared specifics, but I trust him and believe we must respect his decision.

original: Ireland surge past scots ireland maintained their six nations grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over scotland at murrayfield. Hugo southwell's try gave the scots an early 8-0 lead but scores from locks malcolm o'kelly and paul o'connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing denis hickie and third penalty from ronan o'gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon petrie scored a second try for scotland but late scores from john hayes and gavin duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, eddie o'sullivan' side can now look forward to welcoming england to lansdowne road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach matt williams a first six nations victory when italy come to edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.
polished: Ireland impressed in their quest for the Six Nations Grand Slam with a decisive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Although Hugo Southwell's early try gave the Scots an 8-0 lead, Ireland responded with powerful scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell, taking control by halftime. Wing Denis Hickie added a third try, complemented by Ronan O'Gara's precise kicking, which totaled 13 points, further widening the gap. Despite Jon Petrie's second try for Scotland, late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy confirmed Ireland's triumph. This win sets the stage for Eddie O'Sullivan’s team to host England at Lansdowne Road in two weeks. Meanwhile, Scotland, still seeking a first Six Nations victory under coach Matt Williams, will aim to convert their competitive play into points against Italy in Edinburgh.

original: Economy focus for election battle britain's economic future will be at the heart of labour's poll campaign, chancellor gordon brown has said. He was speaking after cabinet members held their last meeting at no 10 before the expected election announcement. He said voters would recognise that labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile the tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the lib dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier the archbishop of canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.
polished: Britain's economic future will be the central theme of Labour's election campaign, announced Chancellor Gordon Brown. His statement followed a meeting with cabinet members at Downing Street, held just before the anticipated election announcement. Brown expressed confidence that voters would acknowledge Labour's success in fostering economic stability and growth, which they pledge to maintain. Meanwhile, the Tories have shared their strategies to address "yob culture," and the Liberal Democrats have detailed their plans to reform the council tax system. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury issued a public letter to all three parties, urging them to refrain from inciting fear during the election. He appealed for a campaign focused on solutions rather than one driven by attempts to scare the public about issues like terrorism, asylum, and crime.

original: Brizzel to run aaa's in sheffield ballymena sprinter paul brizzel will be among eight of ireland's european indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's aaa's championships. Us-based alistair cragg and mark carroll are the only irish athletes selected so far for the europeans who will not run in sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the british trials. In-form james mcilroy will hope to confirm his place in the british team for madrid by winning the 800m title. Mcilroy has been in tremendous form on the european circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in madrid. Corkman mark carroll confirmed in midweek that he would join cragg in the european championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with cragg occupying top spot.
polished:
Paul Brizzel to Compete in AAA's Championships in Sheffield

Irish sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among the eight athletes representing Ireland in this weekend's prestigious AAA's Championships in Sheffield. Notably, Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll, who are based in the United States, are the only Irish athletes so far selected for the European Championships who will not compete in Sheffield.

Brizzel aims to defend his 200m title at the British trials. Meanwhile, James McIlroy, currently in exceptional form on the European circuit, is looking to secure his spot in the British team for the Madrid competition by winning the 800m title. With stellar performances this winter, McIlroy is one of the world's fastest 800m runners and is virtually guaranteed a place in Madrid.

Cork's Mark Carroll, ranked third globally in the 3000m, confirmed midweek that he will join Cragg at the European Championships, where Cragg holds the top spot in the 3000m rankings.

original: Robinson wants dual code success england rugby union captain jason robinson has targeted dual code success over australia on saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads england against australia at twickenham at 1430 gmt. And at 1815 gmt, great britain's rugby league team take on australia in the final of the tri-nations tournament. "beating the aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said robinson. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over canada and south africa, as well as gaining revenge for june's 51-15 hammering by the wallabies. Meanwhile, great britain could end 34 years of failure against australia with victory at elland road.
polished: Jason Robinson, the captain of England's rugby union team, is aiming for a significant dual-code victory against Australia this Saturday. Having transitioned from rugby league to rugby union in 2000, Robinson will lead England as they face Australia at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later, at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will meet Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final. Robinson stated, "Defeating the Aussies in both matches would be a tremendous accomplishment, particularly for rugby league." England is poised to secure their third autumn international win following successful matches against Canada and South Africa, and they hope to avenge their 51-15 loss to the Wallabies in June. Simultaneously, Great Britain has the opportunity to break a 34-year win drought against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

original: Warning over tsunami aid website net users are being told to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site looks plausible because it uses an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, dec has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam e-mail that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts.
polished: Beware of Fraudulent Tsunami Aid Website: Internet users are being cautioned to steer clear of a deceptive website falsely claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site seems convincing as it mimics an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with this fraudulent site and has alerted the authorities about the issue. This site represents another entry in the growing list of scams exploiting the goodwill inspired by the tsunami disaster. The website's link is embedded in a spam email currently in circulation. The email is titled "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and is riddled with poor grammar and spelling errors, common indicators of phishing scams.

original: Iraq to invite phone licence bids iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, saying it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, arab and foreign companies, iraq's ministry of communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the iraqi telecommunications and post company (itpc). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." it also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 february. It also is planning a road-show for investors in amman, jordan.
polished: Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly enhance nationwide coverage in the coming decade. The invitation is open to local, Arab, and international companies, according to Iraq's Ministry of Communications. The selected company will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to establish and operate a fixed-line network that offers voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's current telephone service penetration rate dramatically, from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within 10 years. It also seeks to develop a highly dynamic and visible telecommunications sector. Details of the bidding and tender process will be available on the ministry's website on February 9. Additionally, a roadshow for investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

original: More women turn to net security older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect pcs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.
polished: According to a two-year study, more women and older individuals are taking proactive measures to secure their home computers against online threats. The number of women purchasing software to shield PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware has increased by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. Conducted for the net security firm Preventon, the study indicates that security awareness is expanding among a diverse range of internet users. Notably, 40% of those who purchase home internet security programs are retirees, with this number rising by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Interestingly, more retired women (53%) are investing in security software compared to their male counterparts. This research highlights the evolving demographics and shattered stereotypes of web users, alongside an increasing recognition of the risks associated with high-speed broadband connections.

original: Podcasts mark rise of diy radio an apple ipod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more ipod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. Podcasting takes its name from the apple ipod, although you do not need an ipod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.
polished: Podcasts herald the emergence of DIY radio, with devices like the Apple iPod and other digital music players capable of storing up to 10,000 songs. Many iPod users are increasingly filling this space not just with music but with a diverse range of audio content from various creators. This phenomenon, known as "podcasting," is championed by Adam Curry, a former MTV host and VJ (video jockey). Although the term podcasting originates from the Apple iPod, owning one is not necessary to either create or enjoy a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show that podcasters typically produce from the comfort of their own homes. The necessary tools are simply a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. Once created, these shows are uploaded to the internet for others to freely download and enjoy.

original: Levy takes whitbread novel prize orange prize winner andrea levy has seen her book small island win the whitbread novel of the year award. She is now favourite to win the overall prize after beating booker winner alan hollinghurst's the line of beauty. Geraldine mccaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for not the end of the world. All the category winners go through to compete for the whitbread book of the year title, which carries with it a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges including sir trevor mcdonald, actor hugh grant and writer joanne harris will meet up on 25 january to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker william hill has placed london-based levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.
polished: Andrea Levy, a previous Orange Prize winner, has garnered the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book "Small Island." This victory positions her as the leading contender for the overall prize, having surpassed Booker Prize recipient Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." On another note, Geraldine McCaughrean has triumphed in the children's fiction category for the third time with "Not the End of the World." Each category winner progresses to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which offers a £25,000 prize. A distinguished panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and author Joanne Harris, will convene on January 25 to select the overall winner, with the announcement to follow that evening. According to bookmaker William Hill, Levy's novel, based in London, is favored to win with 6/4 odds.

original: Yukos seeks court action on sale yukos will return to a us court on wednesday to seek sanctions against baikal finance group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue baikal and others involved in the sale of yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' us lawyers will attempt to have baikal assets frozen after the russian government ignored a us court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that baikal - which bought the yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on sunday at a state provoked auction - has strong links with surgutneftegas, russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.
polished: Yukos is set to return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to request sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure entity that has acquired its primary asset. Yukos has announced its intention to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Yukos' American legal team will strive to have Baikal's assets frozen, following the Russian government's disregard for a U.S. court's order last week that sought to halt the sale. The details surrounding Baikal's background and its reasons for purchasing the unit remain uncertain. Russian media have suggested that Baikal— which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) at a state-initiated auction on Sunday—has significant ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

original: Hearts 2-1 livingston hearts wrapped up their scottish cup quarter-final tie against livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over colin meldrum and into the net from a jamie mcallister free kick. Mcallister himself scored the second when he met saul mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but hearts held on. The opening goal came after gus bahoken had clumsily fouled miller 35 yards from goal. Mcallister floated the free kick into the livi box and miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where mcallister raced in to head past meldrum.
polished: Hearts secured their spot in the Scottish Cup quarter-final by overcoming Livingston with a 2-1 victory, thanks to their remarkable start in the opening 10 minutes. Lee Miller drew first blood within the first minute, expertly heading Jamie McAllister's free kick over Colin Meldrum into the net. McAllister quickly followed up, personally adding to the score by meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the far post and sealing the game early on for the hosts. Although Craig Easton netted a controversial goal for Livingston after an hour, Hearts maintained their lead until the final whistle. The first goal was set up following a mistake by Gus Bahoken, who fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister's deft free kick found its way to an unguarded Miller, who leapt above the static Livingston defense to score from 10 yards out. Just ten minutes into the match, Hearts extended their advantage as Mikoliunas dashed down the right flank and delivered a precise cross, allowing McAllister to head past Meldrum.

original: Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz. "why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked in a webcast launching sun's quarterly network computing event in california.
polished: Sun Microsystems has introduced an innovative pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers to rent massive computing power on an hourly basis. This offering, known as the Sun Grid, is priced at just $1 (approximately 53p) per hour, providing users with both processing and storage capabilities on systems managed by Sun. Grid computing is rapidly gaining attention within the company, which views computing capacity as a crucial commodity, on par with traditional hardware and software solutions. Sun has drawn parallels between grid computing and the evolution of utilities like electricity, anticipating a similar trajectory of development. Jonathan Schwartz, Sun's Chief Operating Officer, emphasized this point during a webcast at the company's quarterly network computing event in California, questioning, "Why build your own grid when you can utilize ours for just a dollar an hour?

original: Jamieson issues warning to bigots scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the scottish executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised celtic and rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. Ms jamieson was speaking ahead of the third round scottish cup clash between the glasgow clubs at parkhead on sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week ms jamieson and first minister jack mcconnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.
polished: Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has put bigoted soccer fans on notice, emphasizing her intent to penalize them severely by banning them from attending matches. These exclusion orders are part of a broader initiative by the Scottish Executive to combat sectarianism. Jamieson commended both Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing this issue but stressed the importance of eliminating sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches as a top priority. Her remarks came ahead of the Scottish Cup third-round match between the Glasgow rivals at Parkhead on Sunday. The long-standing sectarian tensions among some supporters of these clubs have now become a major focus for the Executive. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell engaged in discussions with representatives from both clubs to address this pressing matter.

original: Uk debut for kevin spacey movie hollywood stars kevin spacey and kate bosworth attended the british premiere of new film, beyond the sea, in london's leicester square on thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s croooner bobby darin. "this is my tribute to someone i think was a remarkable talent," said spacey, who, as darin, sings all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays darin's wife - real life hollywood actress sandra dee. "i knew absolutely nothing about bobby darin before this film, but now i'm a huge fan," said bosworth, who attended the premiere with british boyfriend orlando bloom.
polished: Kevin Spacey's new film had its UK debut with a star-studded premiere attended by Hollywood actors Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth. The event took place on Thursday at Leicester Square in London. Spacey, aged 45, not only wrote and directed "Beyond the Sea" but also played the lead role, bringing to life the story of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This film is my homage to an extraordinary talent," said Spacey, who performed all 18 songs on the movie's soundtrack. Bosworth, aged 21, portrayed Darin's wife, the real-life actress Sandra Dee. "Before working on this project, I knew nothing about Bobby Darin, but I've since become a fervent admirer," remarked Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

original: Leeds v saracens (fri) headingley friday, 25 february 2000 gmt the tykes have brought in newcastle prop ed kalman and tom mcgee from the borders on loan while fly-half craig mcmullen has joined from narbonne. original: Home phones face unclear future the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the uk, germany, us and south korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends. In the uk 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.
polished: The traditional landline phone in your home may soon become a relic of the past. Recent research conducted by Nokia reveals that a growing number of individuals now rely solely on their mobile phones for all their call-making and receiving needs. The study indicates that over 45 million people in the United Kingdom, Germany, the United States, and South Korea exclusively use mobile phones. While many still retain their landlines due to lower call charges, the majority of participants believe that the future lies with mobile technology. The Nokia-sponsored study also highlighted that mobile and fixed-line phones serve different functions: landlines are favored for longer conversations, whereas mobile phones are preferred for shorter chats, particularly with friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents reported choosing their landline for calls as it remains more cost-effective than using a mobile phone.

original: Melzer shocks agassi second seed andre agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by jurgen melzer in the quarter-finals of the sap open. original: Tories outlining policing plans local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. polished: The UK's opposition Conservative Party has announced a proposal for mandatory health checks for immigrants if they secure victory in the upcoming general election. polished: There is growing discontent within the Cabinet over plans to divert funds from Whitehall to ease the pressure on council tax bills, as acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished: Reducing the legal drink-driving limit could save more lives than previously estimated, according to a new report. Research from University College London suggests that lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood could prevent 65 deaths annually. These findings are being released by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill, which addresses speeding fines but not the drink-driving limit. Conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, the research also indicates that this change could result in 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003, potentially saving the country £119 million each year. A prior estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport report projected that such a reduction might save 50 lives annually.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished: This paper introduces an innovative millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 radiation detector system designed for detecting single charged particles in external beam cancer radiotherapy. The system features a 1x1 μm² diode that captures the energy deposited by a single charged particle within the depletion region. Its array layout provides an extensive detection area of 512x512 μm². Unlike traditional methods that detect voltage drops from radiation, this system measures the pulse width, which is the time required for the voltage to return to its initial state. This approach eliminates the necessity for large, energy-intensive analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC was manufactured using the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, with an average static power consumption of just 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The entire system's functionality has been successfully validated in a clinical setting using a 67.5 MeV proton beam.

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: Research shows that controlling the routing of autonomous vehicles (AVs) can help lessen the adverse effects of selfish routing on overall network efficiency. Nonetheless, it is unrealistic to assume that AVs would willingly submit to external control by a central authority. In this paper, we introduce a combined routing and pricing strategy designed to motivate AVs to participate in centrally managed system-optimal routing by offering toll savings. Meanwhile, AVs that pursue user equilibrium, along with human-driven vehicles, will incur congestion charges. We approach this issue through a bi-level optimization model. The upper level focuses on optimizing dynamic tolls, while the lower level employs a mixed equilibrium simulation for dynamic traffic assignment, accommodating both AVs and human-driven vehicles.

original: Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has encouraged ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. But the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.
polished: Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature-squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This advancement not only brings larger, more tangible objects into the realm of quantum behavior but also inspires the use of mechanical oscillators for processing and communicating quantum information and for serving as precision force sensors that surpass the standard quantum limit. However, the primarily linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a wider range of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states. Early optomechanical theories suggested that this limitation could be overcome by establishing strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations involving quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have yet to reach nonclassical states of motion.

original: Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make decisions. Unfortunately, the evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have learned increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to the deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are hard to capture, as they can be varying quickly along time, different across spammers and target products, and more critically, remained unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address the challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.
polished: Online reviews are crucial for customers when it comes to making informed purchase decisions. Unfortunately, these reviews can be compromised by fake reviews or "spams" inserted by professional spammers. These spammers continue to develop more sophisticated and powerful tactics to evade existing detection methods. Capturing these spamming strategies is challenging as they evolve rapidly, vary between spammers and products, and are often unknown. Moreover, most current detection techniques prioritize accuracy but do not necessarily uphold the reliability of product evaluations. To solve these issues, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and spam detectors tactically compete, focusing on pragmatic objectives beyond mere detection accuracy. The Nash equilibrium of this game yields stable detection systems that are robust against any combination of detection methods.

original: We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the lewis-riesenfeld (l-r) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the l-r invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.
polished: We have developed single-shot shaped pulses designed for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer within a three-level quantum system configured in a lambda arrangement. To achieve high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions that facilitate exact transfer, ensuring that these solutions adhere to a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. From this family, we identify a tracking solution characterized by a single parameter, which effectively controls the fidelity of the transfer, the population within the excited state, and the robustness of the system. We define the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas that results in infidelity exceeding $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses demonstrate superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses when considering moderate pulse areas.

original: In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same form of structure that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over-or under-specified. For gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.
polished: In this paper, we explore the characteristics of the population's negative log-likelihood function associated with Gaussian mixture models, regardless of the number of components involved. Due to the function's nonconvex nature, many local minima exist, which are suboptimal on a global scale, even in scenarios where the mixture components are clearly distinct. We demonstrate that all local minima possess a consistent structural form that partially identifies the true mixture's component centers. Specifically, each local minimum involves either fitting multiple Gaussian distributions to a single true component or fitting one Gaussian distribution to multiple true components without overlap. Our findings are applicable when the true mixture components meet a specific separation criterion and remain relevant whether the number of components is overestimated or underestimated. For Gaussian mixtures comprising three components, we achieve more precise outcomes regarding the separation scaling between the components.

original: We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the calabi-yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by some suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $ x_m $ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, berglund-h\"ubsch-krawitz (bhk) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original calabi-yau orbifold. We give a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.
polished: We examine the link between two methods for constructing the mirror partner of a Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( g \) of the phase symmetries of a hypersurface \( x_m \) within a weighted projective space, specified by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( w_m \). The first approach, known as the Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, involves another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( x_{m^t} \) within it by a dual group \( g^t \). The second approach, proposed by Batyrev, constructs the mirror partner as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the one associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide straightforward evidence supporting the equivalence of these two constructions.

original: In this work, a generalization of the study of the human gait was made from already existent models in the literature, like models of keller and kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is combined in a race process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, trying to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for different speed regimes, indicate that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a relevant quantity in the quantification of this dynamic. An experimental procedure was put into practice in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences and laboratories of the manuela beltr\'an university in bogot\'a, colombia.
polished: In this study, we expanded upon existing models of human gait, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev, to develop a comprehensive understanding. Our hybrid model integrates a strategy for minimizing metabolic energy during a race with a non-linear representation of the movement of the center of mass, aiming to replicate the transition from walking to running. Experimental data across various speeds suggest that the trajectory's perimeter of the center of mass is a significant factor in analyzing this dynamic behavior. This experimental approach was executed in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

original: We present a new mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, that fully resolve close encounters. The method is based on a time regularisation that allows keeping the stability properties of the symplectic integrators, while also reducing the effective step size whenever two planets encounter. We use a high order mvs scheme such that it is possible to integrate with large time steps far away from close encounters. We show that this algorithm is able to resolve almost exact collisions (i.e with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problem such as the solar system. We demonstrate the long term behaviour on systems of six super-earths experiencing strong scattering for 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as mercury and show that for an equivalent cost we obtain much better energy conservation.
polished: We introduce an innovative mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator specifically designed for planetary systems, effectively addressing close encounters. This approach leverages time regularization to maintain the stability characteristics of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size when two planets come close to each other. By employing a high-order MVS scheme, the integrator allows for large time steps when planets are far from such encounters. Our results indicate that this algorithm successfully manages near-exact collisions, where the separation is only a fraction of the planets' physical radii, using the same time step applicable to less perturbed situations like the solar system. We validate the long-term performance on a system of six super-Earths undergoing intense scattering over 50,000 years. Comparing our integrator with hybrid models like Mercury, we demonstrate superior energy conservation at an equivalent computational cost.

original: Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing the hilbert-space dimension with respective to the system size, it is very challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite greenberger-horne-zeilinger (ghz)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. As a comparison, the most efficient witness for ghz-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.
polished: Entanglement plays a vital role in quantum information processing. A commonly used method to identify entanglement is through an entanglement witness, where measuring the witness operator is always positive for separable states but can turn negative for certain entangled states. However, as the system size increases, the dimension of the Hilbert space expands exponentially, making it particularly challenging to design an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. When dealing with $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most resilient witness approach requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can endure up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only necessitates two local measurement settings and can withstand up to $1/3$ white noise.

original: Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure depending only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, which provides a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates could place only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission lisa will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.
polished: In the framework of general relativity, the Kerr spacetime represents the sole stationary solution for an isolated black hole, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We have developed a comprehensive method to extract the multipole moments of any stationary spacetime and have applied this to a broad range of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can disrupt the axial and equatorial symmetry found in the Kerr metric, resulting in a far more intricate multipolar structure. This complexity offers a means to impose phenomenological constraints on fuzzball models. Our numerical results suggest that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute terms) than those of a Kerr black hole with equivalent mass and spin. While current measurements of the quadrupole moment in black-hole candidates impose only minimal restrictions on fuzzballs, future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals by the LISA space mission will significantly tighten these constraints.

original: Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case in which edges can be short term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both expensive to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, using the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component provides more flexibility while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.
polished: Understanding the evolution of graphs over time is a complex task across fields like bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. In the scenario we examine, graph edges represent either short-term interactions (such as messaging) or long-term structural connections (such as friendship). Often, long-term edges are manually defined by humans, which can be costly to establish and may not always be optimal for subsequent analysis. To address these challenges, we introduce a model that combines temporal point processes with variational autoencoders to understand temporal attention between nodes based on their communication patterns. By using the dynamics of node interactions, this method enhances flexibility and resolves issues related to manually defined edges, as temporal attention influences how features are propagated between nodes.

original: Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. Since our pcw has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of pcws. Longer term goals are to achieve strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the gms of the pcw, thereby enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.
polished: We report on the thermally induced transverse vibrations of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW). The waveguide is composed of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. We have developed and validated models to translate the motion of these beams into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe traveling through a guided mode (GM) in the waveguide. This analysis is applicable for probe frequencies both far from and near the dielectric band edge. The PCW was specifically designed for near-field atom trapping, and this study lays the groundwork for assessing potential adverse effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps located close to the waveguide surfaces. Our long-term objectives include creating robust atom-mediated interactions between individual vibration phonons and single photons traveling in the PCW’s guided modes, thus paving the way for quantum-level opto-mechanical systems integrating atoms, photons, and phonons.

original: We establish natural splittings for the values of global mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting comes from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences separate into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.
polished: We introduce natural decompositions for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms linking the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups across successive dimensions are inherently split epimorphisms. This splitting is particularly relevant in the context of equivariant stable homotopy theory. In this framework, the equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum organize into a global Mackey functor, making the splittings instrumental in breaking down certain long exact homotopy group sequences into shorter exact sequences. In the case of the real and complex global Thom spectra, denoted as $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, these splittings affirm the consistency of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

original: Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression is an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as euclid or lsst. In this first paper in a series of two, we use simulations to build a euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of schneider et al. (2019). In addition, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\lambda$cdm cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.
polished: Baryonic feedback effects lead to a dampening of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on smaller scales. The uncertain shape and magnitude of this damping pose significant challenges for forthcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as those conducted by Euclid or LSST. In this first installment of a two-part series, we utilize simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the associated covariance matrix, both of which are adjusted for baryonic influences using the baryonification method outlined by Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we have developed an emulator to provide rapid predictions of baryonic power suppression, enabling us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard ΛCDM cosmology, incorporating both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

original: Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings such as those found in child-centered recordings have been shown to be amongst the most challenging audio files to process. Nevertheless, building speech processing models handling such a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies in which researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To this end, we gathered diverse child-centered corpora which sums up to a total of 260 hours of recordings and covers 10 languages.
polished: Processing spontaneous conversations in real-world environments, like those found in child-centered recordings, is recognized as one of the most complex audio challenges. Successfully developing speech processing models capable of handling such a diverse range of conditions would greatly benefit language acquisition research, which focuses on the quantity and quality of speech children are exposed to and produce. Additionally, these models would be invaluable for early diagnosis and evaluating the impact of interventions. In this paper, we introduce our methodology for creating an open-source neural network designed to categorize audio segments into vocalizations by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations from other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled a diverse set of child-centered corpora, amassing a total of 260 hours of recordings spanning 10 languages.

original: Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to some specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure allows to frame the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function.
