original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished: I'd like to share with you an intriguing glimpse into the future of money, beginning with a fascinating story from a culture in Micronesia known as the Yap, dating back to the early 1900s. The Yap people had a unique form of currency: enormous limestone discs called rai stones. These discs weren't exchanged or physically moved like our coins because they could be incredibly large, with the biggest weighing around four tons and measuring up to 12 feet in diameter. Instead, the Yap maintained a collective memory of who owned shares in each stone. There's a tale of sailors transporting a rai stone across the sea when it unfortunately sank to the ocean floor. Despite the stone's loss, its ownership continued to be acknowledged by the community.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: Imagine being accused of a crime you didn't commit, with no way to prove your innocence. If you protest your innocence, you're likely to be found guilty and face execution. However, if you falsely confess, apologize, and implicate others, you'll be set free. This harrowing choice plagued those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. These individuals suffered due to a paranoia about the supernatural, fervent but misguided religious zeal, and a legal system that prioritized repentance over the truth. Salem, established in 1626 by Puritans—an English Protestant group—was a community where life was strict and isolated. Conflicts with Native American neighbors and French settlers were common.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: Currently, hundreds of thousands of individuals are on transplant lists, awaiting life-saving organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers. Unfortunately, the supply of donor organs is far from meeting this growing demand. Imagine if, instead of waiting, we could engineer entirely new, customized organs from scratch. This is the principle behind bioprinting, an emerging field of regenerative medicine. While we're not yet able to create complex organs, we have made strides with simpler tissues, such as blood vessels and tubes essential for nutrient and waste exchange. Bioprinting resembles 3D printing in that it uses a technique of layering materials to construct a three-dimensional object, one slice at a time.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished: Good afternoon. I'm delighted to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I aim to discuss a phenomenon that is reshaping our world, one we know as "people power." I'll begin with an anecdote, or, for those who appreciate Monty Python, a sketch reminiscent of their humor. Imagine this: it’s December 15, 2010. Someone proposes a wager—you'll gaze into a crystal ball and glimpse the future, knowing it will be accurate. Your challenge is to share this vision with the world. Intrigued, despite the risks, you accept. After an hour, you find yourself in the studios of a national TV network, appearing on a prominent talk show, recounting your extraordinary story.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small minority of dissenters, and they claim that bob dylan is stealing other people's songs.2004. Brian burton, aka danger mouse, takes the beatles' "white album," combines it with jay-z's "the black album" to create "the grey album." "the grey album" becomes an immediate sensation online, and the beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property. "now, "the grey album" is a remix.
polished: Let's start in 1964. Bob Dylan, at just 23 years old, is reaching the peak of his career. Dubbed the voice of a generation, Dylan is producing iconic songs at an astounding rate. However, a small group of critics accuses him of plagiarizing the work of others. Fast forward to 2004, when Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' "White Album" with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." This remix quickly becomes an online sensation, prompting The Beatles' record company to issue numerous cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." "The Grey Album" stands as a notable example of remix culture.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: That's quite an evident statement to begin with. I first made that observation about 12 years ago, focusing initially on developing nations. However, this insight applies universally, as we all hail from various parts of the globe. Consider a map of your own country. You'll likely notice that, in every nation, there are specific areas where qualified teachers are reluctant to work. Ironically, these are often the regions that need quality educators the most and where societal issues tend to arise. In 1999, I embarked on an initiative to tackle this challenge through a straightforward experiment conducted in New Delhi.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.
polished: Currently, the majority of refugees reside in cities rather than in refugee camps, accounting for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. With this urban shift, there is an urgent need for a change in approach and new strategies. Instead of spending resources on building barriers, it would be more beneficial to invest in programs that enable refugees to support themselves. When fleeing, refugees often have to leave their possessions behind, but they retain their skills and knowledge. If given the opportunity to lead productive lives, refugees can not only support themselves but also contribute significantly to their host countries. I hail from the city of Bukavu in South Kivu, located in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and I am the fifth child in a family of 12.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished: I have two questions for you. First: on whose shoulders do you stand? Second: what principles do you uphold? These are questions I always pose to students at the start of my poetry workshops because, often, poetry is viewed as an outdated art form dominated by old white men who seem to have been born old, much like the character Benjamin Button. I present these questions to my students and then share my own responses, summarized in three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, descended from freedom fighters who shattered their chains and transformed the world. They inspire me. These words form a mantra that I repeat before every poetry performance. In fact, I was reciting it in the corner over there, making facial expressions as I did so.

original: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about the five years after graduating from an upstanding liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue called the eight-foot bride, and i love telling people i did this for a job, because everybody always wants to know, who are these freaks in real life. (laughter)hello.i painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, i handed them a flower — and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, i threw in a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.
polished: After graduating from a reputable liberal arts university, I didn't initially make a living from music. For about five years, my day job was quite unconventional. I was a self-employed living statue known as the Eight-Foot Bride. I love sharing this part of my life because it always piques curiosity about the real lives of street performers. On a whim, I decided to paint myself white, stood poised on a box, and placed a hat or can at my feet. When someone dropped money, I responded by offering them a flower along with intense eye contact. If they declined the flower, I would give a wistful, longing gesture as they moved on.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world held its breath as the Soviet Union successfully launched Sputnik, the first-ever artificial satellite. This small metal sphere, under two feet in diameter, sparked a space race between the United States and the USSR that spanned eighteen years and profoundly altered the course of history. It's worth noting, however, that Sputnik was not the first human-made object in space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, which was used by Germany to target Allied cities in the waning days of World War II—a tactic that, while not particularly effective, laid the groundwork for future space endeavors. At the war's end, both the United States and the Soviet Union seized this technology and the brilliant minds behind it, utilizing them to advance their own aerospace ambitions.

polished: I am a cultural enthusiast, one whose daily commute is sustained by my beloved iPod—a device filled with the works of Wagner and Mozart, hits from pop icon Christina Aguilera, soulful tunes by country artist Josh Turner, beats from gangsta rap legend Kirk Franklin, and an abundance of concertos and symphonies. My passion extends to my home theater, where I eagerly consume DVDs, video on demand, and an assortment of television shows. original: [citizens of the world][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale][please stand by for a message from ... ][the secretary-general of the united nations antónio guterres]the climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors and people everywhere. So i'm pleased you are launching ted countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. polished:
Dear Global Citizens,

We are confronted with a crisis of unparalleled magnitude. Please prepare to receive a statement from António Guterres, the Secretary-General of the United Nations. 

The climate emergency is the defining challenge of our era. We find ourselves in a race against time, and unfortunately, we are falling behind. There is an increasing sense of urgency and impatience, particularly among the youth, due to the lack of decisive global action. It is crucial that we see greater ambition from all sectors: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals alike. 

I am encouraged by the launch of TED Countdown. Your influence and innovative ideas can play a pivotal role in accelerating progress towards achieving a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is our only viable path to mitigating the worst impacts of global warming. We possess the tools, scientific knowledge, and resources necessary to succeed. Now, let us engage in this race with renewed political resolve and vigor.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation, a straightforward term for a natural biological process, has been burdened by centuries of stigma, forcing many of us to discuss it in hushed tones. But why is that the case? As I speak to you now, over 800 million women worldwide are experiencing their periods. This process is essential to human existence, yet it continues to be an "embarrassing" topic. From my experiences and those of the women around me, I can tell you it's draining. It's exhausting to discreetly pull a pad in a brown paper bag from your bag, tuck it into your pocket during class, and hurry to the restroom hoping not to draw attention. It's tiring to endure lessons and meetings, feigning normalcy while inwardly battling intense period cramps.

original: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, canada's boreal forest. It stretches right across northern canada, in labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the george river caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when i was there, i couldn't find one of them, but you have the antlers as proof.all across the boreal, we're blessed with this incredible abundance of wetlands. polished: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is located in the heart of Canada's boreal forest, the largest and most pristine forest on Earth. This vast, untouched wilderness stretches across northern Canada and is home to the George River caribou herd in Labrador, which is the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world with approximately 400,000 animals. Sadly, during my visit, I was unable to spot any caribou, though the antlers serve as evidence of their presence. Throughout the boreal forest, we are blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands. Globally, wetlands are among the most endangered ecosystems. These vital ecosystems play a crucial role in purifying air and water, sequestering significant amounts of greenhouse gases, and providing habitat to a vast diversity of species.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other— they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction.one day, while the supreme spirit yaya was out in his gardens, deminan and his brothers snuck into yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.
polished: Before the era of humans, there existed a realm belonging to the gods, characterized by vast fields, plains, and gardens. In this divine landscape roamed four brothers. They were each other’s sole kin, their parentage a mystery. Among them was Deminan, distinguished by skin marred with painful scabs, a burden he bore alone that left him pondering its origin. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya tended to his gardens, Deminan and his brothers stealthily entered Yaya's home. There, after satisfying their curiosity with exploration and indulgence, they noticed a colossal gourd suspended in a corner. In their attempt to examine it, the gourd slipped from their grasp and fell.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. And at the time, there wasn't really that much information about the company, but the little that was there was really impressive. So you wouldn't have to get a big needle stuck in your arm in order to get your blood test done. polished: Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with dual degrees in Molecular and Cell Biology and Linguistics. During a career fair on campus, I secured an interview with a start-up called Theranos. At the time, there wasn't much information available about the company, but the little that was known was quite impressive. Theranos was developing a medical device that allowed for a full blood panel using just a finger-stick of blood. This innovation was intriguing not only because it eliminated the need for large needles, making the process less painful, but also because it had the potential to revolutionize predictive diagnostics.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My journey to becoming a polar specialist and photographer began at the age of four when my family relocated from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. We settled in a small Inuit community of about 200 people, and we were one of only three non-Inuit families there. In this remote area, we had no television, computers, or even a radio. We didn't have a telephone either. I spent all my time outdoors with the Inuit, playing and learning from them. The snow and ice became my playground, and the Inuit were my mentors. This experience kindled my deep fascination with the polar regions.

original: We're seen as the organization that is the bucket for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they stay. We get the people for whom nothing else has worked, people who have fallen through all of the other social safety nets. They can't contain them, so we must. That's our job: contain them, control them.over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very good at that, but that shouldn't make you happy. Today we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We have more black men in prison today than were under slavery in 1850.
polished: We are often viewed as the last resort for addressing failed social policies. We cannot choose who comes to us or dictate how long they remain. We are left to manage individuals for whom all other social safety nets have failed—those who have slipped through the cracks. Other systems can't handle them, so we must. Our task is to contain and control them. Over the years, as part of the prison system, our nation, and society, we have become adept at this. However, this is not an achievement to take pride in. Currently, we incarcerate more people per capita than any other nation in the world. Moreover, there are more Black men in prison today than there were enslaved in 1850.

original: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the rosetta spacecraft. To escort and land the probe on a comet, this has been my passion for the past two years. In order to do that, i need to explain to you something about the origin of the solar system.when we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when the earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted the earth and delivered water to earth. They probably also delivered complex organic material to earth, and that may have bootstrapped the emergence of life.
polished: Let me take you on the remarkable journey of the Rosetta spacecraft, a mission that has fueled my passion for the past two years. Its purpose was to accompany and land a probe on a comet. To truly appreciate this mission, it's essential to explore the origins of our solar system. Imagine a time four and a half billion years ago, when a vast cloud of gas and dust existed. At the heart of this cloud, our sun was born and began to shine. From this same cloud emerged what we now recognize as planets, comets, and asteroids. The prevailing theory suggests that once Earth had cooled after its formation, it was struck by numerous comets. These cosmic encounters brought vast amounts of water to our planet, and perhaps even complex organic molecules that may have initiated the genesis of life itself.

original: Chris anderson: hello, ted community, welcome back for another live conversation. It's a big one today, as big as they get. You know, when we created this "build back better" series our thought was how could we address issues arising out of the pandemic, how could we imagine building back from that. But the events of this past week, the horrific death of george floyd and the daily protests that have followed, i mean, they provided a new urgency which we, of course, simply have to address. polished:
Chris Anderson: Hello, TED community, and welcome back to another live conversation. Today’s discussion is as significant as they come. When we launched the "Build Back Better" series, our aim was to tackle issues stemming from the pandemic and explore how we could rebuild in its aftermath. However, the tragic death of George Floyd this past week and the subsequent daily protests have brought a new urgency to our dialogue that we cannot ignore. Can we emerge stronger and better from this? Before we attempt to answer that question, we must first strive to comprehend the vast significance of this moment.

Whitney Pennington Rodgers: Absolutely, Chris.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping expedition in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt spent his nights amidst the towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and engaged in extended discussions around the campfire with his host and guide, the conservationist John Muir. While Roosevelt was an avid lover of the outdoors, Muir had a purpose beyond recreation for inviting him: Yosemite was under threat. Although it had been designated protected land since 1864, by 1903, the valley faced significant risks of overdevelopment. This was central to a longstanding struggle to reserve land for preservation while making it accessible for public use—objectives that were easier to articulate than achieve. The conflict over Yosemite's future began during the 1849 Gold Rush when miners flocked westward, searching for gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause)my ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, i live in gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing i can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.
polished: Hello. This is my first journey outside the confines of Gaza—I have never ventured beyond its walls until now. I am thrilled to be here. (applause) My lifelong dream has been to become a pilot, to fly an airplane, and to experience the freedom of soaring through the sky. Unfortunately, that dream hasn't come true. Living in Gaza means there is no airport, and all borders are sealed off in every direction. We exist in what is one of the largest open-air prisons worldwide. My only option is to gaze up at the sky. There are days when we are fortunate if we have electricity for only four or five hours. When the weather turns chilly, we gather to build a fire either in front of or atop our homes.

original: I am sorry i cannot show you my face, because if i do, the bad guys will come for me.my journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter. I had just come out of college.then i got a scoop. The scoop was quite a very simple story. Police officers were taking bribes from hawkers who were hawking on the streets. As a young reporter, i thought that i should do it in a different way, so that it has a maximum impact, since everybody knew that it was happening, and yet there was nothing that was keeping it out of the system.so i decided to go there and act as a seller. As part of selling, i was able to document the hard core evidence. The impact was great. It was fantastic.this was what many call immersion journalism, or undercover journalism.
polished: I apologize, but I cannot reveal my face, as doing so would put me at risk from those who seek to harm me. My journey began 14 years ago when I was a newly graduated young reporter. One day, I stumbled upon what seemed like a straightforward story: police officers accepting bribes from street vendors. Although this issue was widely known, no efforts had effectively addressed it. As an ambitious young journalist, I aimed to present the story in a unique and impactful manner. To achieve this, I decided to go undercover as a vendor, allowing me to gather irrefutable evidence of the wrongdoing. The resulting impact was remarkable and powerful. This approach is often referred to as immersion journalism or undercover journalism.

original: One simple vitamin can reduce your risk of heart disease.eating chocolate reduces stress in students.new drug prolongs lives of patients with rare disease.health headlines like these are published every day, sometimes making opposite claims from each other. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. So how can you avoid being misled by grabby headlines?the best way to assess a headline’s credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. We’ve come up with a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines.keep watching for the explanation of the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. These are simplified scenarios.
polished: Every day, health headlines capture our attention with claims like, "A single vitamin can lower your risk of heart disease," or "Eating chocolate reduces stress among students." We also hear about breakthroughs like, "New drug extends lives of patients with rare diseases." However, these headlines often contradict each other or oversimplify the complex findings of the underlying research. This discrepancy arises because catchy headlines tend to overlook the nuanced and incremental nature of scientific studies. How can you ensure that you’re not misled by sensationalistic headlines? The key is to examine the original research that the headline is based on. We've crafted hypothetical research scenarios to illustrate this point for each of these headlines. Stay tuned for an explanation of the first example, and take a moment to reflect when you see the headline. These scenarios are simplified for clarity.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished: When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my younger brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom posed an unexpected question: "What date should we choose for their birthdays?" I replied in disbelief, "The day they were born, of course!" To which my mom responded, "Kristen, neither of your little brothers has a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out their actual birthdays?" This revelation was eye-opening for me. Fast forward 20 years, and I am still deeply engaged with this issue. However, instead of solely focusing on my brothers' lack of birth certificates, I am now working on finding solutions to this problem on a global scale. But you might wonder, what is the connection between birth certificates and international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine being able to connect your mind to a device that promises endless pleasure for the rest of your life. If presented with this opportunity, would you take it? This is the intriguing question posed by philosopher Robert Nozick in his thought experiment known as the Experience Machine. This scenario invites us to envision a world where scientists have created a machine that replicates real life while ensuring perpetual pleasure without any suffering. The trade-off? You must abandon reality permanently, although you would scarcely notice the difference. Your experiences would feel indistinguishable from real life. The natural highs and lows of life would be replaced with a never-ending series of highs. Tempting, isn't it?

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. I was asked as a consultant to see a woman in her 70s — retired english professor who had pancreatic cancer. I was asked to see her because she had pain, nausea, vomiting ... When i went to see her, we talked about those symptoms and in the course of that consultation, she asked me whether i thought that medical marijuana might help her. I thought back to everything that i had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because i had learned absolutely nothing.
polished: Let me recount the most embarrassing incident in my career as a palliative care physician. This took place a few years ago. I was called in as a consultant to assess a woman in her 70s, a retired English professor suffering from pancreatic cancer. My role was to address her issues with pain, nausea, and vomiting. During our consultation, she inquired whether I believed medical marijuana could alleviate her symptoms. Reflecting on my medical school education regarding medical marijuana, I realized, to my chagrin, that I had learned absolutely nothing about it.

original: For the past 24 years, i have been a firefighter in huntington, west virginia. As firefighters, my team and i are tasked with saving lives and property from such disasters as car wrecks, house fires and also life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession.and 10 years ago, i decided to increase my medical knowledge and i received a nursing degree. That was because it became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, as a firefighter, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you have made a difference and everything is ok.
polished: For the last 24 years, I have served as a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. My team and I are dedicated to saving lives and protecting property from various emergencies, including car accidents, house fires, and critical medical situations. As a woman leading a department in a predominantly male field, I decided to enhance my medical expertise by earning a nursing degree ten years ago. This decision was motivated by the realization that the emerging threat to my city, and others across the nation, was no longer a single, manageable disaster. Unlike before, when a firefighter could respond, extinguish the blaze, and leave with a sense of accomplishment, the challenges we face now require a more comprehensive approach to truly make a difference.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the carbon we emit go? Carbon participates in a natural cycle that permeates all living entities: it resides in the soil, the oceans, the atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and other living organisms die, a significant portion of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plant life emerges to reabsorb it. Over millions of years, some of the carbon from ancient trees and marine life transforms into rock or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural occurrences, such as volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon contained in these rocks. Human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, also release this ancient carbon. Currently, human activities release approximately 60 times more carbon annually than all the planet's volcanoes combined.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even the most unappealing creatures in nature hold valuable secrets. Take cockroaches, for instance—despite their off-putting reputation, they possess fascinating capabilities that highlight a profound contrast between natural and human-made technologies: robustness. Robust systems excel in maintaining stability across complex and unfamiliar environments. Astonishingly, cockroaches demonstrate the ability to self-stabilize while traversing uneven terrain. When we equipped them with a jet pack or introduced a disturbance akin to an earthquake, we found that their exquisitely designed legs enable them to maintain balance without engaging any cognitive processes. They effortlessly navigate challenging landscapes, such as grass, without becoming destabilized. Additionally, we observed a novel behavior facilitated by their unique shape, which allows them to naturally roll to one side to maneuver through artificial grass obstacles. Robust systems are capable of performing a variety of tasks using the same structural framework, and this new behavior exemplifies that principle.

original: These are grim economic times, fellow tedsters, grim economic times indeed. And so, i would like to cheer you up with one of the great, albeit largely unknown, commercial success stories of the past 20 years. Comparable, in its own very peculiar way, to the achievements of microsoft or google. And it's an industry which has bucked the current recession with equanimity. I refer to organized crime.now organized crime has been around for a very long time, i hear you say, and these would be wise words, indeed. But in the last two decades, it has experienced an unprecedented expansion, now accounting for roughly 15 percent of the world's gdp. I like to call it the global shadow economy, or mcmafia, for short.so what triggered this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?
polished: In these challenging economic times, fellow TEDsters, I want to lift your spirits by sharing a remarkable, though largely overlooked, commercial success story from the past two decades. This story is comparable, in its unique way, to the achievements of tech giants like Microsoft or Google. The industry in question has managed to thrive even amid the current recession. I am referring to organized crime. While organized crime has been part of society for a long time, recent decades have seen an unprecedented surge, now representing roughly 15 percent of the global GDP. I like to call this the global shadow economy, or "McMafia" for short. But what has fueled this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?

original: If you ask people about what part of psychology do they think is hard, and you say, "well, what about thinking and emotions?" most people will say, "emotions are terribly hard. They're incredibly complex. They can't — i have no idea of how they work. But thinking is really very straightforward: it's just sort of some kind of logical reasoning, or something. But that's not the hard part. "so here's a list of problems that come up. One nice problem is, what do we do about health? the other day, i was reading something, and the person said probably the largest single cause of disease is handshaking in the west.
polished: When asked about which aspect of psychology is challenging, and prompted with "What about thinking and emotions?" most people typically respond that emotions are incredibly difficult to comprehend—complex beyond their understanding. In contrast, they tend to view thinking as more straightforward, equating it to some form of logical reasoning. However, this perception overlooks the true complexity of the situation. For example, consider this scenario: How do we address health issues? Recently, I read an intriguing claim stating that handshaking is possibly the greatest single contributor to disease spread in Western countries.

original: What is a parent?what is a parent?it's not an easy question. Today we have adoption, stepfamilies, surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Shall we tell our child about the sperm donation? if so, when? what words to use? sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father? "as a philosopher and social scientist, i have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. But today, i will talk to you about what i learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family looks a little different.
polished: What does it mean to be a parent? This is not an easy question, especially in today's diverse family structures involving adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate motherhood. Many parents encounter challenging questions and face difficult decisions, such as whether to inform their child about a sperm donation and, if so, when is the right time and which words to choose. While sperm donors are often labeled as "biological fathers," should we really use the term "father" in this context? As a philosopher and social scientist, I have explored these questions concerning the essence of parenthood. However, today I want to share insights gained from conversations with parents and children. I'll demonstrate that, despite the unique appearances of their families, they understand what truly matters in family life.

original: When i look in the mirror today, i see a justice and education scholar at columbia university, a youth mentor, an activist and a future new york state senator. (cheering)i see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison — six years, to be exact, starting as a teenager on rikers island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment i faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something i didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole.a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison.
polished: When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State senator. I see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison—six years, to be precise—beginning as a teenager on Rikers Island for an act that nearly cost someone their life. However, what brought me from that past to my present wasn't the punishment I faced as a teenager in an adult prison or the severity of our legal system. Rather, it was the educational environment of a classroom that opened my eyes to possibilities I never imagined for myself or the justice system at large. Just a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered within the prison.

polished: When you see me, what comes to mind? Perhaps you see a woman of faith, an expert, or maybe even someone akin to a sister. On the other hand, you might perceive me as oppressed, brainwashed, or even mistakenly view me as a threat or a mere delay in an airport security line—which, humorously enough, can be quite accurate at times. original: We need to build a weather service for water. polished: We need to create a comprehensive water monitoring service, similar to a weather service. However, without a collective demand for accountability, there won't be sufficient motivation to finance such an initiative. The first time I spoke at a conference was here at TED, eight years ago. As a recent graduate, I wasn't aware that those few moments on stage would shape the questions I would face over the next decade. Like many people in their twenties, I was eager to tackle global issues, particularly those related to water, with my technological solutions. I had much to learn. It was tempting to believe that our major water quality challenges persisted mainly because they were difficult to detect. I assumed all we needed were simpler, quicker, and more affordable sensors. I was mistaken.

original: Indeed, for 20 years, i worked in finance. I knew everything about finance, for sure. I knew the global economy because it was my life. All the topics that you could bring up about ecology, the end of the world, etc., that i knew like the back of my hand i didn't really believe in them. In 2007, an extremely unusual event occurred, you may remember, the subprime crisis, the collapse of big american banks. It was an electric shock. I had a fair few stormy conversations with my wife about the matter, about my job, on the limits of the model. Besides the crisis, i realized that i was completely wrong, that we were heading for disaster.
polished: For two decades, I dedicated my career to the finance industry, fully immersing myself in the intricacies of the global economy. I was confident in my understanding of every financial nuance. Discussions on topics like ecology or apocalyptic scenarios were familiar to me, yet I regarded them with skepticism. However, in 2007, the unexpected occurred—the subprime crisis hit, leading to the downfall of major American banks. This event was a wake-up call. It prompted intense discussions with my wife about my career and the limitations of the financial model I had been a part of. The crisis led me to a profound realization: I had been fundamentally mistaken, and we were on a path towards disaster.

Those air vibrations are traveling to you, they're hitting your eardrums, and then your brain takes those vibrations from your eardrums and transforms them into thoughts. I hope. polished: I'm communicating with you using language because it's one of the amazing abilities we humans possess. We can convey complex ideas to each other. Right now, I'm producing sounds with my mouth while exhaling. These sounds are creating tones, hisses, and puffs, which generate vibrations in the air. These vibrations travel to your ears, where your brain interprets them and transforms them into thoughts. At least, I hope that's what's happening. (Laughter) This remarkable capability allows us to share ideas across vast distances and time, enabling the exchange of knowledge between minds.

original: There's this quote by activist and punk rock musician jello biafra that i love. He says, "don't hate the media. Be the media." i'm an artist. I like working with media and technology because a, i'm familiar with them and i like the power they hold. And b, i hate them and i'm terrified of the power they hold. (laughter)i remember watching, in 2003, an interview between fox news host tony snow and then-us defense secretary, donald rumsfeld. They were talking about the recent invasion of iraq, and rumsfeld is asked the question, "well, we're hear about our body counts, but we never hear about theirs, why?" and rumsfeld's answer is, "well, we don't do body counts on other people."
polished:
There's a quote I adore from activist and punk rock musician Jello Biafra: "Don't hate the media. Be the media." As an artist, I'm drawn to working with media and technology for two main reasons. First, I'm familiar with them and appreciate their influential power. Second, I have a complex relationship with them, as I am both in awe of and apprehensive about their power—resulting in a paradoxical love-hate dynamic. 

I recall a particular moment in 2003, when I watched an interview on Fox News with host Tony Snow and then-U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld. The topic was the recent invasion of Iraq, and at one point, Snow asked Rumsfeld about the lack of reports on the body counts of the opposing side. Rumsfeld responded, "Well, we don't do body counts on other people.

polished: Are you baking an apple pie? Discount Orange Warehouse has everything you need! After all, fruit is just fruit, isn't it? In 1988, scientist James Hansen testified before the United States Congress, revealing that global warming trends are driven by human activities and will increasingly threaten humanity in the future. Remarkably insightful for the time, don't you think? Searching for the perfect wedding dress? Consider a new spin on a timeless classic—sleek, flattering, and modest, reminiscent of traditional designs. Commercials, could they be any more grating? Fast forward to 1997, when the United States Senate held a hearing on global warming. Expert witnesses noted that certain periods in Earth's history were warmer than the 20th century.

original: Someone once said that politics is, of course, "showbiz for ugly people." so, on that basis, i feel like i've really arrived. The other thing to think of is what an honor it is, as a politician, to give a ted talk, particularly here in the u.k., where the reputation of politics, with the expenses scandal, has sunk so low.there was even a story recently that scientists had thought about actually replacing rats in their experiments with politicians. And someone asked,"why?" and they said, "well, there's no shortage of politicians, no one really minds what happens to them and, after all, there are some things that rats just won't do." (laughter)now, i know you all love data, so i'm starting with a data-rich slide.
polished: Someone once remarked that politics could be seen as "showbiz for unattractive people." By that standard, I feel as though I've truly made my entrance. It's important to acknowledge what a privilege it is, as a politician, to deliver a TED Talk, especially here in the U.K., where the political reputation has nosedived due to the expenses scandal. There was even a recent story about scientists considering replacing rats with politicians in their experiments. When asked why, they humorously responded, "There’s no shortage of politicians, no one really concerns themselves with their fate, and, after all, there are some tasks even rats won't stoop to." (laughter) Now, knowing your love for data, I'll begin with a data-rich slide.
